title: Alberweiler Castle
text:
Alberweiler Castle is a small castle-like structure in the village of Alberweiler, now part of the municipality of <a href="Schemmerhofen">Schemmerhofen</a> in the state of <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. It is situated on a hillside in the centre of the village. The ground and the first floor of the castle are made of stone whereas the upper storeys consist of three projecting <a href="Timber%20framing">half-timbered</a> floors.
History.
A castle is first mentioned in sources dating from the 11th century. It was occupied by <a href="Ministerialis">knight</a>s in the service of the <a href="Graf">Counts</a> of Berg-Wartstein. This early structure was destroyed in 1487 but soon after, towards the end of the 15th century, a new castle was erected at the behest of Bartholome of Warthausen. Some remains of the <a href="circular%20rampart">circular rampart</a> are still visible. Following the extinction of the house of Warthausen zu Alberweiler in 1585, the castle was <a href="Enfeoffment">enfeoffed</a> to the Counts of <a href="Stadion%20%28state%29">Stadion</a> by <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Emperor</a> <a href="Rudolf%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Rudolf II</a>. The castle was renovated in early-<a href="Baroque">Baroque</a> style in the 17th century. The <a href="Portal%20%28architecture%29">gate</a> was also constructed during these <a href="Building%20restoration">restoration</a> works. At around 1700, the castle functioned as residence for the local <a href="Vogt">reeve</a>, the Counts of Stadion residing at <a href="Warthausen">Warthausen Castle</a>, and subsequently went into private ownership during the course of the 18th century. In 1826, the Counts of Stadion sold all rights to the village and the castle to the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Kingdom of Württemberg</a>. Following alterations in 1880 the structure slowly began to fall into disrepair. The castle was extensively restored in the late 20th century and is privately owned today.
